page.title: 05Campanology at Laverstock.
page.content: At St Andrew's Church, two young boys, Martyn and Iain are responsible for the bell chiming. Now, they receive pocket money for ringing the bells at weddings and other church services. Usually Iain rings the heaviest bell and Martyn rings the lighter bell. Ringing starts when the couple come under the arch at the entrance to the Church.{There are two bells recast {by Whitechapel Foundry in 1960, {inscribed 'SAPLOPN'}and housed in an open turret. The height of the bell tower is about 15 metres . The bells have an unusual{ringing arm. Unlike {traditional church}hung bells in this country, there is no wheel joined to the headstock. The bells are only able to be chimed by pulling a right angled metal arm, fitted to the top of the bell. This has a chain attached to the ringing rope,which is jerked sharply.
